@virajjasani as i understood, this change is needed only for Start/Stop sequence during Rolling upgrade, right?

> @virajjasani as i understood, this change is needed only for Start/Stop sequence during Rolling upgrade, right?

Yes @hapylestat , that is one of the reasons but the other one is also to provide 2 more action buttons for RegionServer i.e. graceful start and graceful stop. Hence, clients can decide which one to execute based on their own logic. For test cluster, using normal start/stop might be fine. However, for production clusters, they can use graceful start/stop.

Afaik, while our stack scripts mainly use WebHDFS, they still have some calls to `hdfs dfs` command line, without which the Service Check will fail anyway.

Instead of picking the random host, can we try to look for master components and execute the command there, as chances that master component provided client functionality is higher than using the random host?

why on Enable and Disable dialog the button called "Start"?  It is confusing. Should it be called enable or disable respectively?
Also is unclear, do we have any error handler and user input checker?   As far as i see - the user input is passed "as is" and i have some security concerns about it

> Also is unclear, do we have any error handler and user input checker? As far as i see - the user input is passed "as is" and i have some security concerns about it

Thanks for the review. The only user params for enabling replication are: 
1. Peer cluster ZK quorum, ZK port
2. Parent ZKey for HBase
3. Cluster ID that we would like to provide

For any non-secure cluster A, if the cluster has access to peer cluster ZK quorum, it will take such input and setup replication. However, for secure clusters (used in production), only if cluster A has ACLs open, has access to peer cluster by means of e.g KRB authentication, only then cluster A will be able to setup connection with cluster B.
Hence, for secure clusters, this should not cause any security threat as such. Moreover, taking care of Authentic functionalities and further validations is HBase's responsibility and we can clearly see the replication command failing for security reasons as per HBase replication command execution. What we are trying to add in Ambari is just the way for allowing users to add/update/remove replication peers, which so far users have to do on their own.

@virajjasani What i mean is that "Peer cluster id" value should be verified in the ruby script, that it is indeed id and not something else. While HBase might be in charge for validating, the security breach would be made through Ambari.
@virajjasani yep, exactly.

@hapylestat Addressed all your concerns. PR #3014 is for trunk branch.
Thanks
